On Mon, Jun 9, 2008 at 8:39 PM, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...> wrote:
>
> I understand that. I have also felt this need in the past. When I
> observed that I could solve many of the same problems by writing
> smaller, more focused tests, not only did I stop wanting to log
> assertions, but my designs improved and I delivered more solid
> features sooner. I believe that if JUnit logged its assertions, then
> that would have robbed me of this experience.

First up I work with Phil and we've had this discussion a few times in
the past. For the most part I don't think I would use this feature a
whole ton but there is one case that I can of.

If I'm invited to come and help with a project which is struggling
with their tests (not having done TDD from the start), I can see using
the log files as a way of helping me better understand what's going
on. Are there tests without assertions? Are there tests with many
assertions? etc.

I know that Cedric suggested using log files to measure change in the
number of tests etc. That sounds like work - currently we just count
the number of tests and use EclEmma for coverage. Not perfect - but it
only takes a few minutes.

So for it me it would be a tool of some, but not the greatest value.

Cheers
Mark
